sub_topic: Finding the maximum or minimum value of a trigonometric function
message_1: A rooftop carnival ride rotates riders in a circle 50 feet in diameter. At its highest point, the ride is 25 feet off the ground. The ride completes 2 full rotations every minute. What is the maximum height off the ground that a rider will experience during the ride? (Round your answer to two decimal places, in feet.)
message_2:
To find the maximum height off the ground that a rider will experience during the ride, we need to consider the radius of the circle the ride is rotating in and the height of the ride at its highest point.

The diameter of the circle is 50 feet, so the radius is half of that:

Radius = Diameter / 2
Radius = 50 / 2
Radius = 25 feet

Since the ride is rotating in a circle, the maximum height will be at the top of the circle, which is the radius above the highest point of the ride.

Maximum height = Highest point + Radius
Maximum height = 25 feet + 25 feet
Maximum height = 50 feet

So, the maximum height off the ground that a rider will experience during the ride is 50 feet.
